title: The Truth about Outliers Part One
question_text:
Which of the statements about outliers is TRUE?

I. Outliers are easier to recognize in a histogram than in a stemplot.
II. When a distribution shows a possible outlier, the mean should be calculated two ways - with and without the outlier.
III. When a histogram shows a possible outlier, the bin width should be increased until the suspected value no longer looks like an outlier.
solution:
Statement I is false. A stemplot is very much like a histogram with a bin width of 10. It would be slightly easier to spot an outlier in a stemplot because the actual data values can be read.

Statement II is true. One way to decide if a suspected point is an outlier is to see how much the mean changes when the outlier is removed from the set. If the mean changes significantly, then the point is probably an outlier.

Statement III is false. This sounds a lot like manipulating the data. Changing the bin width to an unusually large size would mean that there would only be a few bars in the histogram. Any shape (skewed or nearly normal) that was previously present in the distribution would be very difficult to see.

Since Statement II is true, the correct answer is Choice 'B'.
